english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Jabbar ibn Abbas: I sat with Ata and began asking him questions, so he said to me: From where are you? I said: From the people of Kufa. Ata said: Knowledge only comes to us from your people.

english_translation: Narrated by Umarah ibn al-Qa'qa': I heard Ibn Shurma saying: I did not see anyone among the living more devoted to worship and more knowledgeable in jurisprudence from (the tribe of) Bani Thor.

english_translation: Narrated by Muhammad: I did not see people with dark heads (Arabs) more knowledgeable than the people I left behind in Kufa, from people who have boldness. Also narrated: A man asked al-Hasan: O Abu Said, are the people of Basra or Kufa (more knowledgeable)? He said: Umar used to begin with the people of Kufa and in it are the houses of all the Arabs.

chainIssues: Mawquf hadith with indirect transmission (أُخْبِرْتُ عَنْ) from Sufyan ibn Uyayna to Muhammad ibn Sa'd
Second part attributes a statement to Umar through al-Hasan al-Basri, which is mursal or mawquf depending on al-Hasan's direct hearing of Umar

potential_issues.impact: Both chains are mawquf, stopped at the tabi'i level (Muhammad ibn Sirin and al-Hasan al-Basri respectively), not reaching the Prophet ﷺ
Muhammad ibn Sa'd uses أُخْبِرْتُ عَنْ (I was informed about) rather than direct transmission, introducing some ambiguity about the strength of the connection
Al-Hasan al-Basri was born after Umar's death (23 AH), so this report from al-Hasan about Umar's statement is not directly from Umar but from other sources

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Merits of scholars from Kufa
Comparison between Basra and Kufa scholars
Importance of Kufa as center of Islamic knowledge
Umar's assessment of different Islamic centers

english_translation: Narrated by al-Shabi: Nobody from the companions of Muhammad ﷺ brought more beneficial knowledge, nor a more knowledgeable companion entered it, than him (meaning Ibn Mas'ud).

english_translation: Ali ibn Abi Talib ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim ibn Abd Manaf ibn Qusai.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

narrators.name: Ali ibn Abi Talib

chainIssues: This is a biographical entry from al-Tabaqat al-Kubra, not a traditional hadith with isnad

potential_issues.impact: This is a genealogical record from al-Tabaqat, lacking a hadith chain structure. It serves as biographical reference material.

Topics: Genealogy of Ali ibn Abi Talib
Family lineage of the Prophet's cousin

english_translation: His kunya was Abu al-Hasan, and his mother was Fatima bint Asad ibn Hashim ibn Abd Manaf ibn Qusai. He witnessed Badr, then settled in Kufa in the marketplace called Rahat Ali in some structures. He did not settle in the palace that the governors before him inhabited. He was killed, may Allah have mercy on him, on the morning of the night of Friday for the seventeenth night remaining in the month of Ramadan in the year forty, and he was sixty-three years old. He was buried in Kufa near the congregational mosque in the governor's palace. The one who carried out his killing was Abd al-Rahman ibn Muljam al-Muradi, and he was from the Kharijites, may Allah's curse be upon him and upon his parents. Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated from Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah have mercy on him, and we have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

narrators.name: Ali ibn Abi Talib
narrators.full_name: Ali ibn Abi Talib ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim ibn Abd Manaf ibn Qusai

english_translation: His name was Malik ibn Uhaib ibn Abd Manaf ibn Zuhrah ibn Killab, and his kunya was Abu Ishaq. His mother was Humainah bint Sufyan ibn Umayyah ibn Abd Shams ibn Abd Manaf ibn Qusai. He witnessed Badr, and he was the one who conquered Al-Qadisiyyah. He settled in Kufa and organized it with divisions for the Arab tribes, built a house in it, and was its governor for Umar ibn al-Khattab and Uthman ibn Affan. Then he was removed from it, and Al-Walid ibn Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'ayt became its governor after him. Sa'd returned to Madinah and died in his palace at Al-Aqiq, ten miles from Madinah. He was carried on the shoulders of men and buried in Al-Baqi'. This was in the year fifty-five. Marwan ibn al-Hakm, who was the governor of Madinah for Mu'awiyah at that time, led the prayer over him. When Sa'd died, he was about seventy years old, and his eyesight had gone. Thus Muhammad ibn Umar said regarding the time of his death, and others said: He died in the year fifty. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

english_translation: His kunya was Abu al-A'war. His mother was Fatima, daughter of Ba'jah ibn Umayyah ibn Khuwalid ibn Khalid ibn Al-Muammur ibn Hayyan ibn Ghani ibn Malik, from Khuzaah. He witnessed Badr. He was in Kufa and settled there, then returned to Madinah. He died at Al-Aqiq, was carried on the shoulders of men, and buried in Madinah. Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas and Ibn Umar descended into his grave. This was in the year fifty, and he was at that time about seventy years old. Thus Muhammad ibn Umar said regarding the time of his death. Others said: Rather, he died in Kufa during the caliphate of Mu'awiyah, and Al-Mughirah ibn Shu'bah, who was the governor of Kufa for Mu'awiyah at that time, led the prayer over him. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

One of the early Muslim scholars

english_translation: Ally of Bani Zuhrah ibn Kilab, with kunya Abu Abd al-Rahman. He witnessed Badr. His migration was to Homs, but Umar ibn al-Khattab transferred him to Kufa and wrote to the people of Kufa: I am sending you Abdullah ibn Mas'ud as a teacher and advisor, and I prefer you with him over myself, so learn from him. He came to Kufa and settled there, built a house in it next to the mosque. Then he came to Madinah during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan and died there. He was buried in al-Baqi' in the year thirty-two, and he was about sixty-six years old. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

english_translation: From Anis from Yemen. He is an ally of Bani Makhzum with kunya Abu al-Yaqzan. He settled in Kufa and remained constantly with Ali ibn Abi Talib, witnessing his battles. He was killed at Siffin in the year thirty-seven and buried there. He was ninety-three years old. He witnessed Badr. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

chainIssues: This is a biographical entry from al-Tabaqat al-Kubra, not a traditional hadith with isnad

english_translation: Freed slave of Umm Anmarr bint Suba' ibn Abd al-Uzza al-Khuzaa'yyah, allies of Bani Zuhrah ibn Kilab. His kunya was Khabbab Abu Abdullah. He witnessed Badr. Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: I heard it mentioned that he was a man from the Arabs from Bani Sa'd ibn Zayd Manat ibn Tamim, and he was captured in slavery, so Umm Anmarr purchased him and freed him. He settled in Kufa and built a house there in the marketplace of Khunais. He died there when Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, returned from Siffin in the year thirty-seven. Ali led the prayer over him and buried him to the outskirts of Kufa. When he died, he was seventy-three years old. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

english_translation: From Al-Aus with kunya Abu Adi. He witnessed Badr. When Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, departed from Madinah, he appointed him as governor of Madinah. Then he wrote to him to join him, so he joined him and remained with him, and witnessed Siffin with him. Then he returned to Kufa and remained there until he died in the year thirty-eight. Ali ibn Abi Talib led the prayer over him and said six takbirs, and said he was from the people of Badr. We have written his account among those who witnessed Badr.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

Recognition by Ali ibn Abi Talib at death

english_translation: His name was Husail ibn Jabir from Bani Abs, allies of Bani Abd al-Ashhal, with kunya Abu Abdullah. He witnessed Uhud and all the battles after that. He died in Madinah in the year thirty-six. News of Uthman's death had reached him there. He had settled in Kufa and Al-Mada'in, and he had descendants in Al-Mada'in. We have written his account among those who witnessed Uhud.

english_translation: Then from Bani Salamah of the Khazraj. He witnessed Uhud. According to Muhammad ibn Ishaq, his name was Al-Harith ibn Rabi'. Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Imarah al-Ansari and Muhammad ibn Umar said: His name was An-Nu'man ibn Rabi'. Others said Amr ibn Rabi'. He settled in Kufa and died there. Ali led the prayer over him there. However, Muhammad ibn Umar denied this and said: Yahya ibn Abdullah ibn Abi Qatadah told me that Abu Qatadah died in Madinah in the year fifty-four, and he was seventy years old.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd

narrators.alternative_names: Abu Qatadah, Al-Harith ibn Rabi', An-Nu'man ibn Rabi', Amr ibn Rabi'

chainIssues: This is a biographical entry from al-Tabaqat al-Kubra, not a traditional hadith with isnad
Multiple name variations recorded with scholarly disagreement about correct name

potential_issues.impact: This is a biographical narrative from al-Tabaqat, documenting Abu Qatadah's life with significant historical disagreement.

Multiple name variations are recorded: Al-Harith ibn Rabi' (per Muhammad ibn Ishaq), An-Nu'man ibn Rabi' (per Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Imarah and Muhammad ibn Umar), and Amr ibn Rabi' (per others), reflecting scholarly disagreement on his actual name.
Muhammad ibn Umar denied the account about Abu Qatadah dying in Kufa, instead reporting he died in Madinah in year 54 at age seventy. This reflects diverging historical sources.

Topics: Biography of Abu Qatadah al-Ansari
Abu Qatadah's participation in the Battle of Uhud
Name variations of Abu Qatadah
Settlement in Kufa
Scholarly disagreement about death location and date

english_translation: His name was Uqbah ibn Amr from Bani Khudarah ibn Auf ibn Al-Harith ibn Al-Khazraj. He witnessed the Night of Aqabah as a young boy. He did not witness Badr but witnessed Uhud. He settled in Kufa. When Ali departed to Siffin, he left him as governor of Kufa, then removed him from it. Abu Mas'ud returned to Madinah and died there at the end of the caliphate of Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan. His descendants have become extinct, and not a single one of them remains.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

narrators.name: Abu Mas'ud
narrators.full_name: Uqbah ibn Amr al-Ansari

english_translation: From Madhaj, his name was Abdullah ibn Qais. Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: I heard it mentioned that he embraced Islam in Makkah and migrated to the land of Abyssinia. His first battle was Khaybar. Umar ibn al-Khattab appointed him as governor of Basra, then removed him from it. He settled in Kufa and built a house there, and had descendants there. Uthman ibn Affan appointed him over Kufa. When Uthman was killed, Abu Musa was in charge of it. Then he came to Kufa and Abu Musa remained with him. He was one of the two arbiters. He died in Kufa in the year forty-two. However, Muhammad ibn Umar informed us through Khalid ibn Ilyas through Abu Bakr ibn Abdullah ibn Abi Jahm, who said: Abu Musa was not among the migrants to Abyssinia. He died in the year fifty-two.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

narrators.name: Abu Musa al-Ash'ari
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Qais al-Ash'ari
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, Abdullah ibn Qais

chainIssues: This is a biographical entry from al-Tabaqat al-Kubra, not a traditional hadith with isnad
Multiple sources conflict on key biographical details

potential_issues.impact: This is a biographical narrative from al-Tabaqat with multiple conflicting accounts about Abu Musa's life.

Muhammad ibn Sa'd initially reports Abu Musa migrated to Abyssinia, but Muhammad ibn Umar contradicts this, stating he was not among the migrants to Abyssinia, reflecting different historical sources.
Muhammad ibn Sa'd reports Abu Musa died in year 42, while Muhammad ibn Umar's source indicates year 52, a 10-year discrepancy requiring further historical investigation.

Topics: Biography of Abu Musa al-Ash'ari
Abu Musa's conversion to Islam in Makkah
Migration to Abyssinia (with scholarly disagreement)
Participation in Khaybar
Governorship of Basra and later Kufa
Role as one of the two arbiters in the Arbitration
Settlement in Kufa and descendants
Scholarly disagreement about death date

english_translation: With kunya Abu Abdullah. He embraced Islam upon the arrival of the Prophet ﷺ in Madinah. Before that, he used to read the scriptures and seek the religion. He was a slave of people from Bani Qurayza, so he made a contract with them. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ paid his ransom for his freedom. He was freed and affiliated with Bani Hashim. His first battle was the Trench. He settled in Kufa and died in Al-Mada'in during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Mani al-Hashimi

english_translation: From Bani Harithah ibn Al-Harith from Al-Aus with kunya Abu Imarah. He settled in Kufa and built a house there. Muhammad ibn Umar said: Then he went to Madinah and died there. Others said: He died during the time of Mus'ab ibn Al-Zubayr and had descendants in Kufa. He narrated from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq. And his brother...

english_translation: One of Bani Al-Harith ibn Khazraj, ally of Bani Abd al-Ashhal from Al-Aus, with kunya Abu Amr. He is one of the ten whom Umar ibn al-Khattab sent to Kufa. He settled there and built a house in the Ansari section. He died there during the caliphate of Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, and Ali led the prayer over him in Kufa.

english_translation: One of Bani Al-Harith ibn Al-Khazraj. Muhammad ibn Umar said: His kunya was Abu Sa'd, and others said: His kunya was Abu Anis. His first battle with the Prophet ﷺ was at Muraysi'. He settled in Kufa and built a house there in the Kinda section. He died there during the time of Al-Mukhtar in the year sixty-two.
